snippet: (41.)—Edinburgh or Mid Lothian, a county of Scotland, about thirty miles long, and in breadth from sixteen to twenty: its superficial extent is 360 square miles, or 230,400 English acres; it is bounded north by the Firth of Forth, and the Almond which separates it from West Lothian or Linlithgowshire, east by the county of Haddington, south by the counties of Lanark, Peebles and Berwick, and on the west corner by part ofthe County of Linlithgow; the general aspect is pleasant; about one third consists of arable land, fertile, and highly cultivated, and affords excellent crops; the Moorfoot and the Pentland Hills pass through the county, the highest point of which rises 1700 feet above the level of the sea.
